awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Amplifying the Efficiency of Tungsten Disulfide (WS2) Thermoelectric Devices
awd_abstract_narration:
Nontechnical:
As much as half of US energy production each year is lost as waste heat. Converting waste heat into electricity could improve energy efficiency dramatically and sharply reduce greenhouse gas emissions. Thermoelectric (TE) devices convert temperature differences into electrical power and have the potential to revolutionize the nation's energy portfolio. An ideal thermoelectric material conducts electricity, but not heat. Metals conduct both, whereas insulators conduct neither. This project challenges this dichotomy by using a novel strategy to dope tungsten disulfide, a two-dimensional (2D) semiconductor. We will enhance its thermoelectric coefficient to maximize the output voltage, increase the electrical conductivity to minimize losses, and lower the thermal conductivity to maintain a large temperature difference. The proposed research will lead to efficient devices for waste heat recovery. This work will also enable high-performance 2D transistors, low-power memory devices, and nanoscale switches for thermal management. The team will work closely with local communities to encourage participation by students from all backgrounds in engineering careers and foster interest in nanotechnology. Outreach efforts will include lab demonstrations, summer internships, and career workshops.

Technical:
The goal of this project is to improve the in-plane thermoelectric efficiency of two-dimensional tungsten disulfide (WS2) devices through engineering their electrical, thermal, and thermoelectric properties via electrochemical intercalation. WS2 has recently emerged as a promising TE candidate due to its large atomic mass (low thermal conductivity), small bandgap (high electrical conductivity), and high Seebeck coefficient. However, it remains challenging to optimize all of the material properties to maximize its TE efficiency and to dope this 2D material to create the p- and n-type pairs needed for TE devices. In this work, we will: (1) achieve p- and n-type doping in 2D materials via anion and cation intercalations; (2) optimize the in-plane power factor of WS2 through doping; (3) reduce the in-plane thermal conductivity of WS2 via phonon scattering by intercalants. Fundamentally, this project will study electrical, ionic, and thermal transport in 2D materials. Practically, this work will pave the way for the wide use of thermoelectric devices to scavenge heat from sources such as electronics and the human body. This work will also develop a doping method for 2D materials, addressing critical issues in 2D electronics such as low drive current and poor contact resistance.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
As much as half of US energy production each year is lost as waste heat. Converting waste heat into electricity could improve energy efficiency dramatically and sharply reduce greenhouse gas emissions. Thermoelectric (TE) devices convert temperature differences into electrical power and have the potential to revolutionize the nation's energy portfolio. In addition, TE devices can also be employed as active cooling devices to lower the over-heating issue in modern computers, which have limited computing performance and caused reliability and potential safety problems. In this project, the team proposed and developed a novel strategy to enhance the thermoelectric efficiency by increasing the electrical conductivity to minimize energy loss and at the same time, lower the thermal conductivity to maintain a large temperature difference, which has been traditionally challenging to achieve simultaneously.

The team developed and demonstrated successful cation and anion doping strategies in two-dimensional (2D) semiconductor thin films. Our electrical characterizations confirmed over 10x enhancements in electrical conductivity. Furthermore, the insertion of dopants resulted up to 80% reduction in thermal conductivity, as confirmed with our nanoscale thermal mapping measurements. Both the increase in electrical conductivity and decrease in thermal conductivity opens exciting opportunity in optimizing the thermoelectric performance of the device, where higher electrical conductivities for minimizing energy loss and lower thermal conductivities for maximizing temperature gradient are preferred.

The team has also created a framework for modelling the active cooling effect from a thermoelectric device integrated with modern electronics. From this model we are able to make prediction of the transient temperature response and its dependence on the inherited properties of thermoelectric materials and actively applied electrical current.

The novel doping strategy developed in this project provides a promising route for improving the electrical conductivity of nanoscale 2D semiconductors and decreasing their thermal conductivities – leading to higher thermoelectric efficiency, in both scenarios. This can lead to transformative applications in energy, flexible electronics, and thermal management. The team has also demonstrated how these thermoelectric effects can be employed in active cooling devices to mitigate the local hot spots in modern microprocessors. This work opens a new path to optimize the design of cooling systems for transient localized hot spots in integrated circuits. Moreover, this work can also be useful for the field of neuromorphic computing and artificial intelligence. Recently, researchers are actively looking for analog memory devices to mimic the synapse in neural networks, which has been difficult to achieve with conventional digital electronics with only binary states. Our doping technique can enable analog tuning of electrical conductivity – leading to high-precision artificial synapse. This can enable the hardware acceleration of artificial neural networks, which has many implications in fields such as automation, self-driving, and artificial intelligence.

The team has worked closely with local communities such as the Pennsylvania Junior Academy of Science (PJAS) to encourage participation by students from all backgrounds in engineering careers and foster interest in nanotechnology and artificial intelligence.
